#Text=Communicate in a Business
#Text=Crisis
#Text=Communication is an important part of any business 's crisis management plan .

#Text=A crisis in business is any occurrence that interferes with business operations and that draws public scrutiny and media attention , and may be anything from serving a customer tainted food to finding a major error in accounting .
#Text=In business , news of crisis spreads fast and a business that is not prepared to handle crisis could be in danger of tarnishing its reputation .
#Text=Therefore , knowing how to handle a crisis when it arises could be necessary to a business 's survival .
#Text=Follow these guidelines for how to communicate in a business crisis .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Prepare for a crisis ahead of time .
#Text=It is important to establish a method for handling a crisis before a crisis happens .
#Text=The following steps will lead to an effective crisis management plan .
#Text=Identify what could go wrong .
#Text=This list will be different for each company , and should be as thorough as possible .
#Text=For example , a cake delivery business may experience a crisis caused by food allergens , an accident during transportation and/or a fire in the kitchen .

#Text=Maintain a fact sheet outlining each and every crisis possibility , as well as the people who must be involved , the methods that must be used to divert the crisis and the audience you must deliver crisis information to .
#Text=Familiarize yourself with your audience .

#Text=Depending on how large your company is , your audience may be composed of 1 or a combination of the following : employees , customers , board members , politicians , the press and/or the media .
#Text=Create a crisis communication plan .
#Text=This plan should direct the flow of information in the event of a crisis .
#Text=Taking into account each of the segments of your audience , decide on the outlets you will use to communicate with your audience when a crisis does happen .

#Text=For example , if your audience is composed of your employees , customers and the press , then your crisis communication plan should incorporate methods for communicating with all 3 of them ; this could mean holding telephone conferences for employees , sending mass emails to customers and writing a press release for newspapers .
#Text=Assign responsibilities to members of a crisis communication team .
#Text=For each item on your communication plan , you will need to assign a task to a communication team member .

#Text=For example , you may delegate the task of drafting the crisis message to the marketing director , the task of conducting telephone conferences to the human resources manager , the task of sending mass emails to your Internet sales division manager and the task of working with newspaper editors to the vice president .
#Text=Additionally , you may want to choose a company spokesperson for high-profile crisis situations .
#Text=Draft your messages .
#Text=When a crisis occurs , it is time to enact your crisis communication plan .
#Text=Gather all of the information you can about the crisis in order to prepare your crisis messages -
#Text=1 tailored to each segment of your audience .
#Text=A crisis message should include the following elements :
#Text=An explanation of the crisis .
#Text=Be as succinct as possible .
#Text=Try to give the audience enough information to satisfy their inquiries but not so much information to seem as though you are trying to explain your way out of something .
#Text=A revelation of your concern .
#Text=Let your audience know that you are genuinely affected by the impact the crisis may have on everyone involved .
#Text=A claim to responsibility , as applicable .
#Text=Own up to your part in the crisis , and offer a sincere apology , if it is warranted .
#Text=A pledge to address the cause of the business crisis , and to work to find a solution .
#Text=Offer a firm commitment to preventing a future repeat of the crisis .
#Text=An assurance that the crisis is an isolated event - not to be confused with the company 's overall efficiency - and that you are still confident in your company .
#Text=However , you should only provide this assurance if you can stand behind it without reservation .
#Text=Do not lie , exaggerate or twist the facts in a way that only provides false hope to your audience .
#Text=Deliver your messages as soon as you possibly can .
#Text=Your goal is to get information to your audience members before they get it from less reliable or damaging sources .
#Text=Use the avenues outlined in your crisis management plan to communicate your messages to each segment of your audience .
#Text=Tips
#Text=Always handle your business affairs in a forthcoming manner , and with honesty and transparency .
#Text=That way , when a crisis does present itself , you have the advantage of a good reputation to aid the effectiveness of your crisis management plan .
#Text=Public relations firms specialize in communicating with the public through media outlets on behalf of businesses .
#Text=You can hire such a firm to help you develop a crisis management plan suited to your business needs and/or to handle communication for your business when a crisis presents itself .
#Text=Your website is a great communication avenue for delivering crisis messages to every segment of your audience .
#Text=Make sure you have an information technology specialist on your crisis communication team so that you can provide real-time updates to your audience when a crisis happens .
#Text=After you deliver your messages , monitor the reaction of the public in the media and on the Internet so that you can respond as needed to counter negative backlash and correct misinformation .
#Text=Warnings

#Text=Avoid withholding a crisis message , as the act of stonewalling will only make you appear uncooperative and unapologetic , which will work against your company 's reputation and make it even harder for you to recover from a crisis .
